content: The Act may be cited as the "Afghanistan Freedom Act of 2001". The rise of the Taliban in Afghanistan led to a decline in human rights, especially for women, girls, and minorities. Millions of Afghans faced starvation in 2001, with the US being the largest humanitarian donor. There are millions of Afghan refugees in neighboring countries and internally displaced persons in Afghanistan. Afghanistan became the world's largest source of illegal opium during Taliban rule. Under Taliban rule, Afghanistan has become a training ground and safe haven for terrorists, including Osama bin Laden and his al Qaeda network. Taliban financing comes from the sale of illegal opium, which is used to fund their war on the Afghan people. The United Nations Security Council adopted Resolution 1267 (1999) demanding the Taliban surrender Osama bin Laden for trial, imposing sanctions under Resolutions 1267 (1999), 1333 (2000), and 1363 (2001) to compel compliance. The Taliban have refused to surrender Osama bin Laden and comply with demands from the United States and the United Nations Security Council following the September 11, 2001 terrorist attack. Afghanistan needs a representative government to ensure the rights of all citizens and promote prosperity. The Taliban's refusal to surrender Osama bin Laden after 9/11 led to the need for a representative government in Afghanistan to protect citizens' rights, ensure peace, eradicate the drug trade, and bring terrorists to justice. The United States policy towards Afghanistan is to remove the Taliban regime to reduce the risk of terrorist attacks and restore freedoms to the Afghan people. Military assistance is provided to Afghan resistance organizations. The President is authorized to provide military assistance to eligible Afghan resistance organizations, with a limit of $300,000,000. Organizations must be committed to removing the Taliban regime in Afghanistan to be eligible for assistance. The curr_chunk discusses the goals of the military assistance provided in Afghanistan, including the removal of the Taliban regime, preservation of territorial integrity, respect for human rights, and suppression of terrorism. Assistance is provided without reimbursement, except for funds appropriated under authorization. Authorization of appropriations for fiscal year 2002 to reimburse defense articles, services, and training provided under subsection (a). Amounts remain available until expended and are in addition to other available funds. Assistance activities authorized under this section. Activities under this section may be undertaken regardless of other laws. SEC. 5. DISASTER AND HUMANITARIAN ASSISTANCE FOR THE PEOPLE OF AFGHANISTAN. Amends the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 to include AFGHAN RELIEF, REHABILITATION, AND RECONSTRUCTION. Congress acknowledges the need for urgent US assistance to help the people of Afghanistan recover from drought and civil war. The President is authorized to provide aid for relief, rehabilitation, and reconstruction efforts, focusing on humanitarian needs such as food, medicine, shelter, and transportation. Assistance will be given in line with established policies and authorities. The President is authorized to provide assistance for relief efforts in Afghanistan, including famine and disease relief through international agencies, private organizations, and Afghan resistance groups. $100,000,000 is authorized for each of the fiscal years 2002 and 2003. In fiscal years 2002 and 2003, $50,000,000 is authorized for assistance to the Afghan people from funds under the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961, for food, medicine, and other aid, regardless of other laws. Establishment of Radio Free Afghanistan. The Broadcasting Board of Governors authorizes grants for Radio Free Afghanistan broadcasts in Afghanistan. RFE/RL, Incorporated must submit a plan within 15 days. $8,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2002 and 2003 for this purpose. For fiscal years 2002 and 2003, $8,000,000 is authorized for Radio Free Afghanistan broadcasts in Afghanistan. An additional $6,000,000 is authorized for International Broadcasting Operations, specifically for surrogate radio broadcasting. $1,500,000 is allocated for a new transmitter for the surrogate radio broadcasting in 2002. SEC. 7. COMPLIANCE WITH MEASURES DIRECTED AGAINST THE TALIBAN BY THE UNITED NATIONS SECURITY COUNCIL. The President must submit reports to Congress every three months identifying foreign governments that have violated measures against the Taliban as directed by UN Security Council Resolutions. The President must submit reports to Congress every three months identifying foreign governments that have violated measures against the Taliban as directed by UN Security Council Resolutions. Each report shall detail violations by foreign governments and evaluate their importance to the Taliban's power in Afghanistan, terrorist groups operating from Afghanistan, and the risk posed to the safety of the United States Armed Forces and other coalition forces. The President is authorized to impose US sanctions if violations are found. The President can impose US sanctions on foreign governments that knowingly violate measures against the Taliban as directed by UN Security Council Resolutions, putting the lives of US Armed Forces and citizens at risk. Sanctions imposed on foreign governments for violating measures against the Taliban include restrictions on providing assistance, issuing licenses for transfers of goods, services, or technology, and applying Trading With the Enemy Act restrictions. SEC. 8. SUBMISSION OF DETERMINATIONS AND REPORTS IN CLASSIFIED FORM. The President may submit determinations and reports in classified form to appropriate congressional committees. SEC. 9. DEFINITIONS. "Appropriate congressional committees" refer to specific committees in the House and Senate. "National" pertains to individuals or entities operating as a business in a foreign country.
